text: The one way to give Meaningful Vote 3 a chance of passing
author: JGForsyth

text: MV3 has no chance of passing unless May offers to resign if it does. As one Cabinet Minister admits, ‘Even that may not be enough’. But it would give the government a chance
author: JGForsyth

text: Tory leadership latest: Matt Hancock the new toast of the donor class. Michael Gove bring urged to run by Mel Stride and co https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/8702461/theresa-may-brexit-deal-must-offer-job-face-general-election/ …
author: JGForsyth

text: If Theresa May was to promise to go if the withdrawal agreement passes, she would show that for her—it really isn’t all about her https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/8702461/theresa-may-brexit-deal-must-offer-job-face-general-election/ …
author: JGForsyth

text: How the chances of no deal rose and fell this week https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/8702461/theresa-may-brexit-deal-must-offer-job-face-general-election/ …
author: JGForsyth

text: This timetable would also give parliament more time to seize control of the process, and so make a softer Brexit more likely
author: JGForsyth

text: The government is no longer in charge of its own destiny, let alone that of the nation. What makes this so humiliating is that power has been ceded not to parliament, but to the European Union
author: JGForsyth

text: The government must now persuade Boris Johnson & Dominic Raab of what they are offering the DUP, in order to get the DUP on board. This makes it much, much harder to get the domino effect going that the government needs to pass the deal https://bit.ly/2ulUtt8
author: JGForsyth

text: If the Tories want to know what the future will hold if they don’t pass the Brexit deal and end up in a lengthy extension, then they should look at what happened to Labour after 1976 https://bit.ly/2ulUtt8
author: JGForsyth

text: The 1976 IMF Crisis destroyed Labour’s claims to competence, drove a wedge between them and their natural supporters the unions, and led to them being out of power for 18 years. What will the 2019 extension crisis do to the Tories? https://bit.ly/2ulUtt8
author: JGForsyth

text: Not since Denis Healey was forced to ask the International Monetary Fund for an emergency loan in 1976 has this country been so humiliated as it will be today https://bit.ly/2ulUtt8
author: JGForsyth

text: In Westminster terms, May’s statement was a nothing burger. But Number 10 will be hoping it taps into voters’ frustrations with the political process
author: JGForsyth

text: As a political journalist my reaction to that May statement is, is that it? But I wonder if voters might find it more powerful--it isn't clear what MPs actually want right now
author: JGForsyth

text: No new policies or arguments in May’s statement. But she is clearly trying to position herself as the defender of the referendum result against a recalcitrant parliament
author: JGForsyth

text: This is petty in the extreme from Corbyn. Given that TIG have 11MPs it is not unreasonable that they are invited to meetings such as this
author: JGForsyth

text: May told Cabinet Ministers this afternoon that she wants to set MV3 up as her deal v no deal. But the danger for Downing Street is that Labour MPs don’t take this framing seriously, while ERG ones do
author: JGForsyth

text: What Theresa May told Boris Johnson yesterday
author: JGForsyth

text: Tusk is saying that the U.K. can only have a short extension if the deal passes. That doesn’t mean that there could not be a long extension if the deal fails again
author: JGForsyth

text: Yesterday’s meeting between Theresa May and Boris Johnson showed how far from promising to resign to get her deal through, May is https://blogs.spectator.co.uk/2019/03/what-theresa-may-revealed-to-boris-johnson/ …
author: JGForsyth

text: When Boris Johnson asked Theresa May what would change in the second part of the Brexit negotiations, Theresa May replied that the Brexit Department would have more autonomy. So, she is clearly not yet prepared to say that she’ll go if her deal passes https://blogs.spectator.co.uk/2019/03/what-theresa-may-revealed-to-boris-johnson/ …
author: JGForsyth

text: Question is how Remain-leaning MPs and others see this. Do they think it is May's deal v no deal or do they think they can repeal Article 50 altogether if May's deal fails again?
author: JGForsyth

text: Striking that May's letter doesn't say anything about what the UK won't do during this extension, no offer to sit out Council meetings or anything like that
author: JGForsyth

text: May letter to Tusk requesting an extension all premised on the government winning MV3, nothing in there about what happens if it is defeated again
author: JGForsyth

text: How this might play out: Application for an SO24 debate granted, Bercow then decides that SO24B does not apply and allows amendments to be tabled to the motion. These amendments change the neutral motion and so the House agrees to a substantive proposition
author: JGForsyth

text: Suspect today won't feel much like international day of happiness in the Commons
author: JGForsyth

text: Worth remembering that international law trumps domestic law. So, if an extension is agreed, the U.K. will—in the eyes of international law—be a member of the EU regardless of what happens with the SI
author: JGForsyth

text: The Tory mood is hardening in favour of May going, but the DUP are less sure this is a good idea. They want to know that whoever succeeds her will not allow regulatory differences between Great Britain and Northern Ireland
author: JGForsyth

text: Understand that DUP sounded out Brexiteer leadership candidates out about GB matching NI on regulations, and were not reassured by their answers  https://blogs.spectator.co.uk/2019/03/why-the-dup-are-worried-about-tory-succession/ …
author: JGForsyth

text: I really don’t think that John Bercow, who volunteered—entirely unnecessarily—that he had voted Remain, is trying to usher in a no deal Brexit
author: JGForsyth

text: When the Hansard is up, will be worth analysing Bercow’s answer to Benn and Whittingdale. To Benn, he seemed to imply that only changes agreed with the EU would count as substantial. But to Whittingdale, he appeared to set a lower bar
author: JGForsyth

text: To say that Bercow is enjoying this would be an understatement of epic proportions
author: JGForsyth

text: But if that was your view, why did you table the amendment in the first place?
author: JGForsyth

text: Bercow now attacking Leadsom and Pincher for being on their phones. It is becoming clear that Bercow’s bar for the government bringing this back, is going to be really quite high
author: JGForsyth

text: Worth noting that Chris Bryant didn’t push his amendment trying to block MV3 to a vote last week. If he had been confident the House didn’t want it to be brought back, surely he would have pushed it to a vote?
author: JGForsyth

text: I think the chances of a general election have just gone up a notch
author: JGForsyth

text: Bercow accuses Neil O’Brien of being in ‘close regulatory alignment’ with the government’s whips office. He’s not even bothering to try and hide it anymore
author: JGForsyth

text: Neil O’Brien urges Bercow to be ‘a modern speaker for modern times’, prompting a long speech from Bercow about all the modernising things he has done as Speaker
author: JGForsyth

text: Bercow indicates that only changes agreed with the EU would count as a substantial change, so bar being raised for the government
author: JGForsyth

text: Leadsom has now arrived
author: JGForsyth

text: Mark Francois now arguing that this ruling should rule our further Cooper, Benn style amendments which would see the Commons take over the order paper
author: JGForsyth

text: If the DUP back the deal, you could argue that would be because they do not think the deal is ‘substantially the same’, certainly as regards Northern Ireland. But would that be enough for Bercow?
author: JGForsyth

text: The question now is, what bar the government has to get over to show that the deal is not ‘substantially the same’?
author: JGForsyth

text: Bercow now paying extensive tribute to Bill Cash, who has just backed up Bercow’s ruling
author: JGForsyth

text: Chief Whip trying to make a point of order after Bercow says he would block an MV3 on a package that is ‘substantially the same’, which is unusual and a sign of how serious this situation is for the government
author: JGForsyth

text: Not sounding good for the government this
author: JGForsyth

text: Lamont and Lilley both in the peers gallery for Bercow’s statement
author: JGForsyth

text: Crucially, May promising to go would not just help with Brexiteer rebels. At least a third of the 9 Tory MPs who voted against MV2 for non Brexiteer reasons, would back the deal if May said she would step down
author: JGForsyth

text: Before the next meaningful vote, Theresa May should make clear that she will go if the withdrawal agreement passes https://blogs.spectator.co.uk/2019/03/may-should-pledge-to-resign-its-not-too-late-to-save-her-legacy/ …
author: JGForsyth

text: I think even with DUP on board there are 25 to 50 Tories determined to vote against. A May promise to go helps get that number down
author: JGForsyth

text: An office holder in the ERG tells me that if May offered to go (and DUP satisfies), number of Brexiteers rebels would fall to 20 or so
author: JGForsyth

text: Why the EU is not going to reject a U.K. request for an Article 50 extension
author: JGForsyth

text: Unexpected trivia, Matt Hancock tells @spectator health summit says that one of his ancestors was a leading Luddite
author: JGForsyth

text: DUP negotiations going relatively well, am told better than 50:50 chance that the government can have them on board for MV3
author: JGForsyth

text: What’s the last thing you want when your voice is going? A meeting with a heavy smoker. But that is what Theresa May had to endure on Monday night when she met Jean-Claude Juncker
author: JGForsyth

text: Downing Street need a carrot to get wavering Brexiteers to back the deal, and the only carrot available is May’s departure  https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/opinion/8649785/theresa-may-begging-eu-brexit-deal/ …
author: JGForsyth

text: If DUP do back deal, and think it is 60/40 they will, question becomes how many Brexiteers climb down Jacob’s ladder and how many Labour come across. Downing Street think they can absorb 25 Tory rebels  https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/opinion/8649785/theresa-may-begging-eu-brexit-deal/ …
author: JGForsyth

text: 60:40 that the DUP back MV3, according to one Cabinet Minister close to the talks. East West lock making a big difference to them  https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/opinion/8649785/theresa-may-begging-eu-brexit-deal/ …
author: JGForsyth

text: Emmanuel Macron wanted to use the backstop to force the UK to make concessions on unrelated issues. After this week’s changes, the risks of that now happening is negligible
author: JGForsyth

text: This is an absolutely crucial point from new analysis of the backstop by three distinguished lawyers for ⁦⁦@Policy_Exchange⁩ The EU knows the UK wants to leave the customs union so, legally, it can’t just stonewall any U.K. proposal that doesn’t include a CU
author: JGForsyth

text: I would say this wouldn’t I, but think ⁦@FraserNelson⁩ is spot on about why Tory MPs should get this Brexit deal over the line on Tuesday
author: JGForsyth

text: A pain for the government that Bryant pulled his amendment, if it had been defeated Bercow would have had to allow a third meaningful vote. Now, up to him
author: JGForsyth

text: ⁦@katyballs⁩ has the scoop on a tempestuous meeting of the political Cabinet. Essential reading
author: JGForsyth

text: Benn amendment defeated. Chief Whip and his deputy do a kind of half handshake, half fist bump
author: JGForsyth

text: Benn amendment
author: JGForsyth

text: Government defeat Lucy Powell amendment by three. Tight as anything but suggests government might just knock back the Benn amendment too
author: JGForsyth

text: What matters about the second referendum amendment is not that only 85 MPs voted for it, but that 334 voted against. So, there isn’t a majority for it even with Labour front bench support
author: JGForsyth

text: Only 85 votes for the second referendum amendment, and notably an absolute majority of the House against
author: JGForsyth

text: @katyballs on what happened at today’s tempestuous meeting of the political Cabinet
author: JGForsyth

text: You might think that the Brexit negotiations so far have been embarrassing, even humiliating. But the moment the UK requests a full-on extension, things will become much, much worse. The UK will be a supplicant
author: JGForsyth

text: The more time there is between 24 June 2016 and the day the UK leaves, the softer Brexit will be, as the pull of the referendum result weakens. That’s why Brexiteers should want May’s deal to pass next week https://bit.ly/2TDenPl
author: JGForsyth

text: If Bryant amendment defeated tonight, then will be hard for Bercow to justify blocking MV3 as the House will have indicated that it wants to vote again
author: JGForsyth

text: ‘A long delay is a catastrophe for her as there would be time for a move for her’, one Cabinet Minister on Theresa May and the politics of an extension  https://www.spectator.co.uk/2019/03/meltdown-three-years-on-and-we-are-no-closer-to-a-brexit-resolution/ …
author: JGForsyth

text: All that is certain at the moment is that nothing is certain—and that should alarm Brexiteers. The further we get from June 24th, 2016, the softer Brexit will be https://www.spectator.co.uk/2019/03/meltdown-three-years-on-and-we-are-no-closer-to-a-brexit-resolution/ …
author: JGForsyth

text: Expectation in Whitehall is that MV3 will be on Tuesday
author: JGForsyth

text: The case for making Meaningful Vote 3 a free vote https://www.spectator.co.uk/2019/03/meltdown-three-years-on-and-we-are-no-closer-to-a-brexit-resolution/ …
author: JGForsyth

text: 3 ways that ministers think that Meaningful Vote 3 can pass https://bit.ly/2TDenPl
author: JGForsyth

text: I really would urge you, and particularly if you are opposed to prosecutions, to read this piece by @douglaskmurray on Bloody Sunday. It makes the case for what is happening better than anything else I’ve read
author: JGForsyth

text: This 2001 UN Security Council Resolution could be about to become quite important. It is significant that Ireland was on the Security Council at the time and supported it https://bit.ly/2gSIIT9
author: JGForsyth

text: Cabinet Ministers will urge Theresa May to make meaningful vote 3, a free vote. Theory is that this would help to get Labour MPs to vote for it
author: JGForsyth

text: As if the government didn’t have enough problems, there is now a major row between the whips and Number 10
author: JGForsyth

text: Meaningful vote 3 coming in the next 7 days
author: JGForsyth

text: Major row brewing between whips office and Number 10. Sounds like one of May's team was telling ministers they could abstain and not be sacked at the same time as the whips were trying to get these ministers to vote with the government. Am told whips absolutely incandescent
author: JGForsyth

text: So, meaningful vote 3 by this time next week
author: JGForsyth

text: Note that unlike last night, May said nothing about the whipping arrangements for tomorrow’s vote
author: JGForsyth

text: Government extension motion will set out 2 paths. 1) Technical extension to pass a deal 2) A long extension which would mean the U.K. would have to take part in EU Parliament elections
author: JGForsyth

text: Government defeated by a significant margin on the amended motion
author: JGForsyth

text: Word of a resignation in the lobbies tonight
author: JGForsyth

text: Commons now voting on government’s motion with Spelman amendment. Things could be about to get even more interesting
author: JGForsyth

text: 164 votes for Malthouse. Will be very interesting to see which Tories backed it
author: JGForsyth

text: Word from the lobbies is that Hunt, Javid and Williamson are all voting for Malthouse
author: JGForsyth

text: Looks like government Chief Whip@and deputy Chief Whip sitting out Malthouse
author: JGForsyth

text: Government defeated on Spelman by four votes
author: JGForsyth

text: Superb essay by @DouglasKMurray in forthcoming @spectator on Bloody Sunday. Food for thought for anyone who opposes the idea of prosecutions. Will post link tomorrow
author: JGForsyth

text: Apologies, silly typo. Should be progress, not process
author: JGForsyth

text: Understand that Geoffrey Cox met with the DUP this morning and that process is being made. Senior figures in government think they might be able to do something that would enable the DUP to back the deal
author: JGForsyth

text: Free votes, Cabinet collective responsibility in tatters: will be fascinating to see whether a new PM can return to the status quo ante, or whether this is the new normal
author: JGForsyth

text: Hammond line about the need to build consensus across the House, which is not government policy, is another reminder of how discipline is breaking down.
author: JGForsyth

text: Hammond talking about ‘building a consensus across the House’ on Brexit, a very different tone from Theresa May
author: JGForsyth

text: 3 year spending review will be concluded by the autumn budget if there’s a Brexit deal, says Hammond
author: JGForsyth

text: OBR's forecast has economy growing in each of the next five years. But in none of these years, is growth forecast to hit 2%
author: JGForsyth

text: Very different mood today than after the 1st meaningful vote. Several of those who voted against regretful. Lots to encourage those in government who want meaningful vote 3 after the extension vote and before the European Council
author: JGForsyth

text: The sixty-plus Tory Brexiteers who voted against May’s deal seem remarkably unconcerned about what will follow its defeat
author: JGForsyth

text: Remarkable to think that last night there was a genuine sense of optimism among ministers that they might be able to get close today. That Hope was crushed by Cox’s legal advice
author: JGForsyth

text: Corbyn pushes general election on his response to May. Could we see another confidence vote soon?
author: JGForsyth

text: Free vote on no deal. May justifies it by the referendum precedent, but for the governing party to have no position on this issue is remarkable
author: JGForsyth

text: May confirms no deal vote tomorrow
author: JGForsyth

text: Government lose by 149, so at the worst end of expectations
author: JGForsyth

text: May just came in, has what looks like a typed up speech with her
author: JGForsyth

text: An interesting, and important, take on how hard it would be to prove that the EU was not acting in good faith
author: JGForsyth

text: The question for Theresa May this evening is whether it is better to try and seize initiative at risk of splitting party further—announce that she is requesting an extension—or to have things done to her by parliament
author: JGForsyth

text: May’s voice is going. When opposition MP heckles, ‘not again’ she shoots back, ‘you should hear Jean-Claude Juncker’s voice’
author: JGForsyth

text: The things that Theresa May needed to happen to have a chance of passing her vote this evening, are just not happening. Looking like a three figure defeat
author: JGForsyth

text: May is winning over some Tory MPs despite legal advice. But problem for her is she starts two hundred and thirty votes down
author: JGForsyth

text: Am told May warning Tory MPs of losing Brexit and a devastating party split. But questions focusing on Cox’s warning that the legal risk remains unchanged
author: JGForsyth

text: This is very bad news for the government. Hard to see now how the vote doesn't go down, and by a significant margin
author: JGForsyth

text: Cox making a statement. Inevitable as he would have been UQed otherwise
author: JGForsyth

text: My growing sense is that this is going to break decisively one way or the other
author: JGForsyth

text: What May has got on the backstop isn’t simple—it is not a time limit or straightforward exit mechanism. So an awful lot will turn on how much of an appetite for a deal, the DUP now have
author: JGForsyth

text: Has May got enough? All depends on what Cox and then Dodds say, and whether there’s enough of an appetite for a deal https://bit.ly/2TI20Rq
author: JGForsyth

text: That press conference adds to the sense that everything now turns on what Nigel Dodds concludes. If it is good enough for him, May is at the races
author: JGForsyth

text: Word from Cabinet is that arbitration on backstop doesn't refer to the ECJ
author: JGForsyth

text: May and Juncker up now
author: JGForsyth

text: My take on Dodds question, not hostile but clearly not enough yet. So all hinges on the unilateral U.K. statement and what it does
author: JGForsyth

text: Dodds says he wants to know when the ‘extremely important’ other part of the negotiation—eg unilateral U.K. statement—will be concluded. Lidington says he hopes they’ll be concluded overnight at the latest
author: JGForsyth

text: IDS suggests delaying meaningful vote to Wednesday to give Commons time to question AG and scrutinise changes
author: JGForsyth

text: Dodds looking to get in
author: JGForsyth

text: 2 joint statements to be laid tonight. Joint interpretative instrument and a joint addition to the political declaration
author: JGForsyth

text: Lidington says ‘legally binding changes secured’
author: JGForsyth

text: Lidington says ‘negotiations still taking place in Strasbourg’
author: JGForsyth

text: Lidington up now. Starts with an apology for the lack of advance notice
author: JGForsyth

text: If the Tusk /Juncker letter is turned into a protocol, then there is a case that the UK could quit the backstop if it was becoming permanent because that would breach the Good Friday Agreement. This would mean Cox could change his legal advice & deal might pass
author: JGForsyth

text: Is this the way out of the impasse over the backstop?
author: JGForsyth

text: Is this what would enable Geoffrey Cox to change his legal advice?  https://blogs.spectator.co.uk/2019/03/the-may-be-a-brexit-breakthrough-on-the-backstop/ …
author: JGForsyth

text: HMG’s view of the precise legal meaning of this section of the Tusk / Juncker letter, could be about to become very important
author: JGForsyth

text: For what it is worth, there is more optimism on the HMG side now than there was this morning. Take your pick from, it is always darkest before the dawn or before it goes totally black
author: JGForsyth

text: Interesting straw in the wind: influential, loyalist Tory MP tells me that if May’s deal fails, it would be better to pull stumps and go for a general election than let Letwin amendment pass. Says May can’t be PM in name only
author: JGForsyth

text: Which begs the question, is May going to Strasbourg to discuss what was rejected yesterday morning or to discuss something new?
author: JGForsyth

text: Where EU ambassadors are being told things are
author: JGForsyth

text: Is there any way that May’s deal could pass on Tuesday?
author: JGForsyth

text: Extension vote on Thursday likely to be accompanied by an amendment mandating indicative votes and requiring the government to try and negotiate what the Commons votes for. Government would be in office but not in power
author: JGForsyth

text: 2 things needed for May’s deal to pass on Tuesday. Enough on the backstop to satisfy the DUP & May promising to stand down ASAP https://bit.ly/2VMhcdF
author: JGForsyth

text: One minister fully briefed on the negotiations tells me that, ‘we’re at what the hell do we do time’ https://bit.ly/2VMhcdF
author: JGForsyth

text: 1 outcome next week would avoid a crisis: some progress on the backstop, May’s deal passing and a new PM coming in to do the next phase of the negotiations. All other roads lead to crisis https://bit.ly/2VMhcdF
author: JGForsyth

text: Gavin Barwell has told ministers that if the government gets nothing more on the backstop, it might put Cox’s rejected proposal to the Commons to try & demonstrate that it would get the deal through  https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/8596589/brexit-brexiteers-wont-back-theresa-mays-deal-softer/ …
author: JGForsyth

text: If Brexiteers won’t back Theresa May’s deal, then Brexit is only going to get softer  https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/8596589/brexit-brexiteers-wont-back-theresa-mays-deal-softer/ …
author: JGForsyth

text: The episode is yet another reminder of how little the UK and the EU understand each other’s domestic politics
author: JGForsyth

text: Giving legal force to the Tusk & Juncker letters isn’t nothing. But by presenting it in conjunction with an offer to return to the NI only backstop, the EU is almost guaranteeing that it’ll land badly in Westminster
author: JGForsyth

text: May’s problem is that everyone thinks that they got what they want by voting against her Brexit deal
author: JGForsyth

text: Brexiteers who think they are going to get a better Brexit by voting down May’s deal are making some heroic assumptions  https://bit.ly/2H6kwNz
author: JGForsyth

text: 2 big dangers of an extension for Brexiteers. 1). What does the EU demand in return for granting it? 2). It would be accompanied by parliament trying to take control and push through a softer Brexit  https://bit.ly/2H6kwNz
author: JGForsyth

text: The essential problem for May’s deal https://www.spectator.co.uk/2019/03/will-brexiteers-miss-their-best-chance-at-brexit/ …
author: JGForsyth

text: The leader from the new issue of The Spectator
author: JGForsyth

text: This cannot be sensible. Do think universities should be liable for some of the debt if their students never earn enough to pay back their tuition  loan
author: JGForsyth

text: Not good news from Brussels
author: JGForsyth

text: If you’re interested in the future of UK politics, do go to @jameskanag and read the various threads he has posted today. Lots of food for thought there
author: JGForsyth

text: ‘Chinese hackers have targeted more than two dozen universities in the U.S. and around the globe as part of an elaborate scheme to steal research about maritime technology being developed for military use', from v interesting WSJ report on US concerns
author: JGForsyth

text: Properly thought provoking column from ⁦@gideonrachman⁩ this morning. Well worth five minutes of your time
author: JGForsyth
